title: How to Make a 'Sepak Takraw Ball' Ornament from a Plastic Bottle

steps.headline: Imagine the shape of this polyhedral ornament as if it were a planet.
steps.description: This will help with the method for creating it. There is one piece that serves as the "equator" (in this article, it is the red piece), and the remaining pieces can be viewed as the Arctic and Antarctic polar regions, depending on the manner in which they are added.

steps.headline: Cut off the top and bottom parts of the plastic soda bottle.
Use the center "tube" of the bottle to cut the rings from.
steps.description: Note where the join of the tube meets; this join line will form your reference point for sticking down the tape from start to finish.

steps.headline: Start at one end of the center tube.
steps.description: Carefully stick the red tape around the tube close to one end, to form a complete circle. This red circle will form the "equator" of the polyhedral ornament.

steps.headline: Join the red tape circle at the tube's join line.
steps.description: Make a fine cut from the edge of the tube along the join line, just to the edge of the red tape circle.

steps.headline: Take the next color (in this example, blue) and proceed to stick it around the tube as before but don't tape it down completely.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/So6_405.JPG/460px-So6_405.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/So6_405.JPG/759px-So6_405.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Instead of taping this circle down, use tape-mount (disposable tape) to insert under the colored tape. Instead of adhering the end of this circle to the plastic tube, it will stick to the tape-mount, moving freely.

steps.headline: Repeat using the next 4 colors, placed equally along the tube.
steps.description:
There should be a total of 5 colored rings, plus the red equator ring. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/So8_920.JPG/460px-So8_920.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/So8_920.JPG/759px-So8_920.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":472,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":779.4871794871794,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}In each case, adhere to the tape-mount and not to the plastic tube. Thus, apart from the red "equator" ring, all the other tape rings should be attached to the tube all the way except for the last part, which will sit on the tape-mount.

steps.headline: Carefully cut out each colored ring.
steps.description: Gently pierce the tube with a pair of scissors and cut around each ring, leaving an even amount of plastic tube on each side of each colored ring.

steps.headline: Repeat until all 5 colored rings have been cut into individual rings, as well as the red equator ring.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/So11_58.JPG/460px-So11_58.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/So11_58.JPG/760px-So11_58.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":599,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":989.7674418604652,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}This should be the end result of your efforts so far.

steps.headline: Create the "South Pole" or Antarctic design.
steps.description:
This will be held in place by tacking with tape; use tape that is easy to remove. With each ring, interweave the pieces alternately (under, over, under, over, etc.). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/So12_209.JPG/459px-So12_209.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3f/So12_209.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":468,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":773.8181818181819,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Hold the blue and green rings vertically together, crossed over. Slide the silver ring horizontally around both rings. Weave the silver ring under the green ring and over the blue ring. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/So13_566.JPG/460px-So13_566.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/So13_566.JPG/760px-So13_566.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":420,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":693.9130434782609,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Tack in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/So14_26.JPG/460px-So14_26.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/So14_26.JPG/760px-So14_26.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":506,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":836.1493123772102,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Add the gold ring. Weave in and out so that it is positioned to form another part of the overall circular shape. Tack in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/So15_299.JPG/459px-So15_299.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/So15_299.JPG/759px-So15_299.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":388,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":641.0434782608696,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Weave the last circle in and out. Tack in place.

steps.headline: Weave in the equator circle (the red piece).
steps.description:
Weave so that it intersects alternately with the rest of the rings. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Ball-equator_636.JPG/459px-Ball-equator_636.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Ball-equator_636.JPG/758px-Ball-equator_636.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}The finished ball. If you are happy with this shape, glue the tacked ends into place. Or, proceed to the next steps.

steps.headline: Make the North Pole or Arctic pentagon.
steps.description:
This pentagon is located inside the ornament. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Ball-s-Pole_871.JPG/460px-Ball-s-Pole_871.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Ball-s-Pole_871.JPG/759px-Ball-s-Pole_871.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":351,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":580.4395604395604,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Refer to the image here when placing the rings. Weave around the respective circles and adjust to create the necessary gaps to create the pentagon.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Adhesion_106.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Adhesion_106.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":238,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":393.2173913043478,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} Tape the ends together as shown, then glue into place to strengthen and maintain the desired shape.
steps.description: (Note that the reference to "bottle" in the image refers to the "rings".)

steps.headline: Use the ornament decoratively.
steps.description:
You can use the Sepak Takraw decoration for such decorative projects as celebratory ornaments, a display object, or as shown here, it can add artistic flair to an ordinary vase: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Ball-vase1_994.JPG/460px-Ball-vase1_994.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/f7/Ball-vase1_994.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":524,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":865.040650406504,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Ball-vase2_791.JPG/460px-Ball-vase2_791.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7f/Ball-vase2_791.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":469,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":775.2276867030965,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Ball-base3_540.JPG/460px-Ball-base3_540.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3f/Ball-base3_540.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":558,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":921.2121212121212,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

text:
Imagine the shape of this polyhedral ornament as if it were a planet. This will help with the method for creating it. There is one piece that serves as the "equator" (in this article, it is the red piece), and the remaining pieces can be viewed as the Arctic and Antarctic polar regions, depending on the manner in which they are added. Cut off the top and bottom parts of the plastic soda bottle. Use the center "tube" of the bottle to cut the rings from. Note where the join of the tube meets; this join line will form your reference point for sticking down the tape from start to finish. Start at one end of the center tube. Carefully stick the red tape around the tube close to one end, to form a complete circle. This red circle will form the "equator" of the polyhedral ornament. Join the red tape circle at the tube's join line. Make a fine cut from the edge of the tube along the join line, just to the edge of the red tape circle. Take the next color (in this example, blue) and proceed to stick it around the tube as before but don't tape it down completely. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/So6_405.JPG/460px-So6_405.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/So6_405.JPG/759px-So6_405.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Instead of taping this circle down, use tape-mount (disposable tape) to insert under the colored tape. Instead of adhering the end of this circle to the plastic tube, it will stick to the tape-mount, moving freely. Repeat using the next 4 colors, placed equally along the tube. There should be a total of 5 colored rings, plus the red equator ring. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/So8_920.JPG/460px-So8_920.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/So8_920.JPG/759px-So8_920.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":472,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":779.4871794871794,"licensing":"

"}In each case, adhere to the tape-mount and not to the plastic tube. Thus, apart from the red "equator" ring, all the other tape rings should be attached to the tube all the way except for the last part, which will sit on the tape-mount. Carefully cut out each colored ring. Gently pierce the tube with a pair of scissors and cut around each ring, leaving an even amount of plastic tube on each side of each colored ring. Repeat until all 5 colored rings have been cut into individual rings, as well as the red equator ring. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/So11_58.JPG/460px-So11_58.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/So11_58.JPG/760px-So11_58.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":599,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":989.7674418604652,"licensing":"

"}This should be the end result of your efforts so far. Create the "South Pole" or Antarctic design. This will be held in place by tacking with tape; use tape that is easy to remove. With each ring, interweave the pieces alternately (under, over, under, over, etc.). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/So12_209.JPG/459px-So12_209.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3f/So12_209.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":468,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":773.8181818181819,"licensing":"

Weave so that it intersects alternately with the rest of the rings. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Ball-equator_636.JPG/459px-Ball-equator_636.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Ball-equator_636.JPG/758px-Ball-equator_636.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.3478260869565,"licensing":"

Weave around the respective circles and adjust to create the necessary gaps to create the pentagon. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Adhesion_106.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Adhesion_106.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":238,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":393.2173913043478,"licensing":"
